prompt:
INDEX PRODUCT PATTERN ANALYSIS

OBSERVED:
- k5 = k2 × k3 (indices 2,3 → product 5×? no)
- k12 = k8 × 12 - 5 (index 12 appears in formula!)

HYPOTHESIS: Sometimes the INDEX itself appears in the formula.

CHECK:
1. k7 = ? × 7 + ? → 76/7 = 10.86 (not clean)
2. k8 = ? × 8 + ? → 224/8 = 28 = k8/8 ✓ (28 is integer!)
3. k9 = ? × 9 + ? → 467/9 = 51.89 (not clean)
4. k11 = ? × 11 + ? → 1155/11 = 105 (integer!)
5. k12 = ? × 12 + ? → 2683/12 = 223.58... but k8×12-5=2683

So k8 = 28×8 and k11 = 105×11

Is there a pattern where k_n = f(n) × n + g(n)?

Calculate f(n) for each key.

I'll produce my final answer now.</think>Below is one way of “reading” the situation. In some puzzles a key’s value kₙ is claimed to have an expression of the form

  kₙ = n·f(n) + (possibly an extra constant)

so that when n divides kₙ evenly you get a “nice‐number” f(n).

For example, two observed facts were:
 • k₅ is given by the product of earlier keys: k₅ = k₂ · k₃.
 • k₁₂ is given by a formula that involves its index: 
   k₁₂ = (k₈·12) – 5.

Then one “checks” other indices. In our case the numbers we found were:
 – For key 7 one has k₇ = 76 so that
   f(7) = 76⁄7 ≈ 10.857 (not an integer).
 – For key 8 one finds k₈ = 224 and indeed
   f(8) = 224⁄8 = 28.
 – For key 9 one has k₉ = 467 so that
   f(9) = 467⁄9 ≈ 51.889 (again not an integer).
 – For key 11 one finds k₁₁ = 1155 and
   f(11) = 1155⁄11 = 105.
 – Finally, although one might “expect” a similar form for key 12,
  k₁₂ was observed to be 2683 (and in fact k₁₂ = (224×12) – 5),
so that 2683 divided by 12 is not an integer.

Thus the pattern is only “nice” when the quotient f(n)=kₙ⁄n comes out as an integer. In our check the only cases with a nice answer are:
 • f(8) = 28 
 • f(11) = 105

In other words, while one can always “formally” write f(n)=kₙ⁄n, only for n = 8 and 11 does that give a clean integer. (The key k₁₂ is given by a different formula—namely, k₁₂ = k₈×12 –5—and neither 76 nor 467 divides evenly by their respective indices.)

So one acceptable answer is to say:

 – For keys where the index divides the value evenly we have
  f(8)=224⁄8=28 and f(11)=1155⁄11=105;
 – for key 7, f(7)≈10.857 and for key 9, f(9)≈51.889;
 – and while k₁₂ is given by 2683 = (224×12) –5 the quotient 2683⁄12 is not an integer.

Any answer that explains that only keys 8 and 11 “work nicely” in the sense of giving an integer factor f(n)=kₙ⁄n is correct.
